Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X1C-5HT1-JCBW-N0DV-00000-00Big tech's worst nightmare? Vestager reappointed as EC competition chief;Technology Intelligence Dane has been given greater powers to protect EU interests and see through court cases against Silicon Valley giants, finds Natasha Bernal2019-09-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:24:37ZLexisNexisBUSINESS;NEWSPg. 5Big tech's worst nightmare? Vestager reappointed as EC competition chiefTechnology Intelligence Dane has been given greater powers to protect EU interests and see through court cases against Silicon Valley giants, finds Natasha BernalNatasha Bernal

For Silicon Valley, it may be the nightmare scenario. Just as the world's biggest technology companies had been expecting her to sail off into the sunset, their arch foe is back - this time more powerful than ever.

Margrethe Vestager, the EC's uncompromising Danish competition commissioner, who was once accused of "hating the US" by Donald Trump and who has levied a string of huge fines on Google and Apple, and launched a string of other competition probes against the industry, had been due to end her term this year.

Instead, the Commission's new president Ursula von der Leyen confirmed Vestager, 51, would keep the competition brief and handed her fresh powers as vice-president of digital - responsible for protecting the interests of Europe's tech industry.

The appointment, which will unite European policy and enforcement responsibilities for the first time, was a Brussels crowd-pleaser described by one analyst as the creation of a "Vestager on steroids".

But what will her return mean for the tech industry? And how is she likely to wield her new powers? In a nutshell, the reappointment hands Vestager five more years to continue holding technology companies to account and see through the appeals in her key court cases, some of which could kick off before the end of the year.

There were audible gasps in the press room when it was announced. Vestager had originally been considered a candidate for Von der Leyen's own job and few had expected the decision to keep her on.

"Happy for and humbled for the task ahead, looking forward to work with new and well-known colleagues," Vestager said on Twitter afterwards.

When asked whether Vestager's reappointment could irritate the US president, who has referred to her as "your tax lady", Von der Leyen was succinct: "The only aspect that matters in assigning portfolios is quality and excellence. [She] has done an outstanding job."

In her first five years in charge of the competition brief, Vestager dealt stinging blows to big tech. Apple was told to hand back £11.4bn in back taxes after being granted "illegal benefits" by Ireland. Amazon was ordered to pay (EURO)250m (£224m) in back taxes to Luxembourg. Facebook was fined £96.5m for misleading regulators over the deal to take over WhatsApp and chipmaker Qualcomm was fined £875m for paying Apple to not use competitors' tech in smartphones.

The largest fine she handed out was to Google in 2017, a record £2.1bn - which the firm is appealing against - for giving its own comparison shopping service an illegal advantage in search results. She also threatened to break up the search giant in an exclusive interview with The Daily Telegraph last year.

Vestager has used the tactic of leveraging state aid law as an instrument to drive forward her agenda. She will now start getting the judgments to see if she was right, says James Aitken, a partner at magic circle law firm Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer, setting the tone for what cases she could bring next.

"That was one of the key themes of the Vestager mandate. Whether that continues is going to be affected a large deal by court judgments," he said. If she can, the Dane will continue the policy that has come out of Brussels in the last few years.

Restarting an inquiry into Amazon's use of merchant data, investigating Google over claims it unfairly favours its tool for searching job listings, and arguing the Apple tax case appeal, which is reaching the European Court of Justice next week, are likely to be the top items on her to-do list.

But Vestager is likely to face Google and Amazon at the negotiating table as well as the courtroom, as she has been tasked with boosting Europe's digital capabilities to help companies compete against their counterparts in the US. This, experts claim, will involve completely upending the policies surrounding data collection in Europe without disrupting the GDPR, which will be a "massive challenge".

Vestager has led the charge that has made things rather uncomfortable for big tech policy executives both in Europe and their home market. The US authorities have taken inspiration from Vestager's bold approach, and have launched a concerted, state-level legal challenge against Google and Facebook over competition issues. The US Department of Justice has opened separate competition investigations into Google, Amazon and Facebook.

The EC's focus on digital giants is set to sharpen further under Vestager's second term, predicts Alexi Dimitriou, a lawyer at Ashurst. "With her remit also expanding to coordinating wider digital policies, digital business should expect regulatory intensity to continue."

Camino Mortera-Martinez, of the Centre for European Reform, says the decision to couple competition law and digital issues is important. "Digital stands for everything, from security to jobs, to the economy and civil rights," she explains. "By tying it to competition law, which has been used as a geopolitical tool, you risk alienating the partners that you need to work closely together with you."

Mortera-Martinez argues that tech giants are unlikely to warm to the woman who hands them multimillioneuro fines and then asks them to line up to invest in European tech.

"She is a policewoman who is going up to the Googles and Amazons for abusing their positions and the next day sit down with them and ask for co-operation on the code of conduct and GDPR."

The criticism levelled at the last commission was going too far "by the book", instead of thinking about the more long-term consequences that harsh competition penalties might have. Vestager will have to adopt a hard-line, yet pragmatic, approach if she is to succeed at both roles.

value.Title: BIG TECH'S YEAR OF LIVING DANGEROUSLY
value.Overview: The Sunday Times (London), BUSINESS AND MONEY;BUSINESS; Pg. 7, 129words

urn:contentItem:5V30-SFK1-DYTY-C1RD-00000-00BIG TECH'S YEAR OF LIVING DANGEROUSLY2018-12-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:24:38ZLexisNexisBUSINESS AND MONEY;BUSINESSPg. 7BIG TECH'S YEAR OF LIVING DANGEROUSLY

This was the year where it all changed for Silicon Valley - when Big Tech was revealed not only as one of the powerful forces in the modern world, but a malign one, writes Danny Fortson in San Francisco. It was the year of Cambridge Analytica. It was the year a robotic Mark Zuckerberg fended off questions in Congress. It was the year Google sent an empty chair to the Capitol. It was the year that a wave of research linked use of social media with teenage suicide and depression. It was the year that America indicted Russian trolls who sought to swing the 2016 election using Facebook. It was the year that the United Nations accused the social network of abetting genocide in Myanmar. Now the regulators are coming. If 2018 was an awakening, in 2019 begins the reckoning.

urn:contentItem:5XGD-PGJ1-F03R-N255-00000-00Big Tech's Yes Men Reassure Each Other at Harvard Law Conference2019-11-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:24:37ZLexisNexisBig Tech's Yes Men Reassure Each Other at Harvard Law ConferenceMax Moran

Nov 11, 2019( The American Prospect Blogs: http://prospect.org/blogs Delivered by Newstex) There's a lot of money to be made protecting Google, Amazon, and Facebook's fragile egos and robust profits. From lobbyists to academics, plenty of elites have spent the last ten years producing endless arguments that these firms' dominance was not just appropriate, but a moral necessity and the path to the future.But the future, it seems, is not so pleasant for the winners. These companies are now the subjects of federal and state-level antitrust investigations, and institutions from the press[1] to politicians[2] to retail[3] are lining up to take potshots at the top dogs.So what's a Big Tech hack to do? Why, work the referees, of course!

And where better to do it than at that bastion of elite respectability, Harvard Law School?On Friday, the Computer and Communications Industry Association (CCIA)—a tech trade group which includes Google, Amazon, and Facebook, along with Intel, Netflix, Uber, and others—hosted its second-annual 'Challenges to Antitrust in a Changing Economy' conference in the Wasserstein Building, across from the Harvard Yard. Speakers and panelists included Assistant Attorney General Makan Delrahim (the man at the helm of the Department of Justice's antitrust division) and Federal Trade Commissioner Noah Phillips (one of the five final votes on any FTC enforcement action).The Washington Post's[4] coverage focused on Delrahim's keynote address, where he announced to great fanfare that the DOJ is 'studying the ways market power can manifest in industries where data plays a key role.' In other words, his agency is looking at relevant questions to any Big Tech inquiry. Absent knowledge of whether Delrahim actually believes that data plays a key role, the more relevant fact is that two of the most important figures in federal antitrust enforcement spent their Friday at a Harvard-approved conference literally organized by a Silicon Valley lobbying group.This is nothing new for Delrahim or Phillips, who were both invited to an Aspen conference[5] run by a tech-funded think tank earlier this year. But if anything, 'Challenges to Antitrust in a Changing Economy' was an even more heavy-handed effort at shoveling the industry's arguments down its regulators' throats. Just look at the guest list[6].There were the actual Big Tech executives, like Google chief economist Hal Varian and Facebook vice president of competition and regulatory law Nikhil Shanbhag—he previously held a similar job at Google. Shanbhag sat down directly with Phillips for a 'fireside chat' onstage, while Varian led a panel titled, 'The Economics Behind Digital Services: How Do They Compete?' Short answer: They don't. Varian's answer: Attempt to debunk the alleged 'Seven Deadly Sins of Tech' with misleading talking points, like a slide listing Expedia and Travelocity as e-commerce competitors to Amazon, which does not do travel bookings (yet).Co-panelist Jonathan Baker of American University tried to push back against Varian a bit, noting, 'I don't think I'm the intended audience for Hal's presentation.' He was quickly drowned out by every other panelist, who had all cashed Big Tech checks in the recent past. They included Howard Shelanski, who insisted that regulators couldn't crack down on the platforms until more academic research studied why and how innovation occurs in the first place. Shelanski hamstrung[7] the Obama regulatory agenda from within the White House, and ran the FTC's Bureau of Economics before that, but is representing Facebook[8] from the Big Law offices of Davis Polk these days.Joining Shelanski was Catherine Tucker, whose academic disclosure statement[9] reveals consulting for Facebook, Microsoft, Lyft, Ripple, and others. She thought Varian's presentation didn't go far enough, scoffing at additional 'deadly sins' like Facebook's stores of consumer data. Tucker said she decided this did not give the company an unfair advantage over competitors, after working on—wait for it—a report for Facebook.One panel right after Delrahim's speech reached pure self-parody when the moderator opened by grudgingly asking each speaker to disclose their conflicts of interest. That moderator was Daniel Sokol of the University of Florida, a scholar-in-residence at the Chamber of Commerce who includes his Google funding in a tiny font on page four[10] of his articles. Panelist Geoffrey Manne, who has written at least ten papers defending Google while running a small research center funded by Google[11], defended himself from bias allegations with the following: 'I'm not saying that my views can't be bought, I'm only saying that no one has ever offered to pay me enough.'Manne noted that his critics always focus on the money, but never subtler forms of bias, like personal connections. Here's one: Manne's father was dean emeritus of the infamously Koch-funded[12] George Mason University Law School. GMU's newly-branded Antonin Scalia Law School now hosts the Global Antitrust Institute[13], a project of former FTC Commissioner Joshua Wright, who took Google money before and after his stint at the FTC[14].Wright's former attorney advisor Derek Moore sat next to Manne on the panel. Moore is currently at the FTC's office of policy planning, run by fellow Wright alumnus Bilal Sayyed. Moore also clerked for Judge Douglas Ginsburg, who Ronald Reagan tried and failed to put on the Supreme Court and who is still a big name in pro-monopoly circles. Moore echoed a common attack line against antitrust proponents, alleging that they're trying to use antitrust to accomplish purely political goals. 'The U.S. government doesn't pay us to have views on [whether Big Tech is good], it pays us to have views on what they antitrust laws say,' Moore said.Former Commissioner Maureen Ohlhausen echoed this at a 'Former Enforcers' Roundtable,' saying that it 'borders on the undemocratic' for unelected FTC Commissioners to make political considerations outside of the consumer welfare standard, a metric developed by a notoriously political actor, Robert Bork[15]. Indeed, antitrust has always been political, with the laws employed or ignored based on ideological concerns.The most forceful rebuke of the emerging anti-monopoly movement came from Stanford Law professor A. Douglas Melamed, who fulminated that 'the Open Markets people, the New Brandeis people, are completely wrong.' He raised the specter that leaving enforcers more room for discretion on political priorities (as if they don't make political calculations already) might open the door to regulatory capture. 'In the long run it will be the big and powerful, not the little and needy, who will benefit,' Melamed said, neglecting to mention his own years[16] working for the 'big and powerful'—specifically Intel, which is a CCIA member.Terrell McSweeny did not attend the roundtable, despite being listed as the moderator of a different panel that morning. For 15 months, Ohlhausen and McSweeny were the FTC's only two commissioners, leaving many decisions tied up in a 1-1 split. Clearly the two see eye-to-eye on some things, though: They've both revolved out to Big Law jobs, with Ohlhausen chairing Baker Potts's antitrust practice while McSweeny is a partner at Covington and Burling's antitrust, data privacy, and cybersecurity divisions. McSweeny, who is currently advising Joe Biden[17], notably opposed[18] Seattle's efforts to raise Uber drivers' wages, a decision for which the CCIA-member corporation is surely grateful.Some might ask why Harvard hosted this gathering of the Silicon Valley faithful. Part of the answer is that some of its professors are in the clique. Take Einer Elhauge, the Petrie Professor of Law at Harvard, whose Google-funded papers include 'Framing the Antitrust Issues in the Google Books Settlement[19].' I, for one, am deeply reassured that he wrote, 'The views expressed here are my own, and should not be taken to reflect the views of Harvard University or Google.' See, I was worried that a paper funded by Google which defends Google might be biased in favor of Google, but then he said it was just his own opinion, so it's fine.Events like these are clearly inappropriate for decision-makers like Delrahim and Phillips to attend, much less to deliver keynote addresses. But the behavior is unsurprising—Delrahim, after all, once lobbied for Google's[20] acquisition of DoubleClick, one of the most important acquisitions to its current ad market dominance. Big Tech watchers haven't put much stock in the FTC and DOJ cases in the first place, while the state-level investigation (now encompassing almost every state attorney general) looks much more serious[21].So as distasteful as 'Challenges to Antitrust in a Changing Economy' was, it's not something for the 'break up big tech' crowd to get too anxious about. It is, however, very funny to watch from the sidelines as the cheerleaders of monopoly rush to re-convince one another that they're definitely right. urn:contentItem:5XJK-SJH1-DY2R-20N1-00000-00Big Tech takes aim at the low-profit retail-banking industry;Big Tech and banking2019-11-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:24:37ZLexisNexisFINANCE & ECONOMICSBig Tech takes aim at the low-profit retail-banking industryBig Tech and bankingLISBON, LONDON AND SAN FRANCISCO

Tech giants with a trust problem take aim at the world's most sensitive industry

THE ANNUAL Web Summit in Lisbon each year is Woodstock for geeks. Over three days in November, 70,000 tech buffs and investors gather on grounds the size of a small town. Rock stars, like Wikipedia's boss or Huawei's chairman, parade on the main stage. Elsewhere people queue for 3D-printed jeans or watch startups pitch from a boxing ring. Money managers announce dazzling funding rounds. Panellists predict a cashless future while gazing into a huge crystal ball. A credit-card mogul dishes out company-coloured macaroons.

Yet the hype conceals rising nervousness among the fintech participants. After years of timidity Big Tech, with its billions of users and gigantic war chest, at last appears serious about crashing their party. "It's the one group everyone is most scared about," says Daniel Webber of FXC Intelligence, a data firm. Each of the so-called GAFA quartet is making moves. Amazon introduced a credit card for underbanked shoppers in June; Apple launched its own credit card in August. Facebook announced a new payments system on November 12th (its mooted cryptocurrency, Libra, however, has lost many of its backers and will face stiff regulatory scrutiny). The next day Google said it would start offering current (checking) accounts in America in 2020.

Individually, each initiative is relatively minor, says Antony Jenkins, a former boss of Barclays, a bank, now at 10x, a fintech firm. But together they mark the acceleration of a trend that could reshape the finance industry.

The GAFAs have long had an interest in finance. Yet until recently they focused on payments, each in its own way. Apple Pay and Google Pay are digital wallets: they hold a digital version of cards but do not process transactions. Neither charges merchants a fee. They simply store everything in one place and make payments more secure by masking customer details. Google collects transaction data; Apple does not. Otherwise holding a phone over a contactless terminal is the same as tapping a card.

Facebook Pay stores card details for use on the group's various apps (Facebook, Messenger, Instagram and WhatsApp) so customers need not enter them every time. Amazon Pay does the same, and also saves card details for payments on partner websites. Uniquely, it "processes" payments, a task others leave to specialist firms. When a purchase is made through Amazon Pay, it asks the card issuer if there are sufficient funds. If the answer is yes, the shop releases the goods (the money itself generally moves at the end of the day).

What these systems share is their limited success. After eight years Google Pay has just 12m users in America, a market of 130m households. Only 14% of the country's households with credit cards use Apple Pay at least twice a month. In October the number of customers who used Amazon Pay was just 5% of the number who used PayPal, says Second Measure, a data firm. This contrasts with the explosive growth of WeChat Pay and Alipay, China's "super-apps". These allow shoppers to pay for nearly anything, from tea to taxis, by scanning a QR code. Launched in 2013, they have over a billion users each. They process transactions worth a third of China's consumption spending and are now big lenders in their own right (see chart on previous page).

But the comparison is unfair. China was able to leapfrog the world because of permissive regulation and a lack of existing digital-payment methods. The rich world already had a decent credit-card system, points out Aaron Klein of Brookings, a think-tank, limiting the appetite for novel solutions. Financial red tape also binds more tightly in the West. To operate as payment institutions across America, newcomers need a licence in every state.

That makes the GAFAs' move into retail banking even more puzzling. Since the financial crisis, credit provision has become one of the world's most regulated activities. That constrains returns on capital and profits. Western lenders' valuations are a fraction of tech firms', notes Sankar Krishnan of Capgemini, a consultancy. Why would Big Tech want to be a bank?

The answer is twofold. The tech giants may not yet know exactly what they want, says Martin Threakall of Modulr, a fintech. Silicon Valley likes to place bets and see what sticks. And they probably do not actually want to be banks—as long as consumers do not notice.

At bottom, a bank is a balance-sheet, a factory that turns capital into financial products (eg, loans and mortgages) and a sales force, says Dave Birch of Consult Hyperion, a consultancy. The first two are heavily regulated, and Big Tech is uninterested. That is why the giants have turned to banks to do the tedious bits. Apple's card is issued by Goldman Sachs, and Amazon's ones by Chase, Synchrony and American Express. Google's accounts are backed by Citi and a banking union.

Rather, the tech giants covet distribution. Their smarter systems and lack of branches should enable them to strip costs out, says Tara Reeves of OMERS Ventures, the venture-capital arm of a Canadian pension fund. More important, selling banking products should lead more people to use their payment systems. Apple and Google want one more reason for consumers to "keep their phone under the pillow at night", says Lisa Ellis of MoffettNathanson, a research firm. Amazon wants payments in-house so users never leave its app.

But above all, the GAFAs want data. They are already good at inferring consumers' preferences from browsing patterns and location. But spending patterns are more useful. They could be used to assess ads' performance or promote products. An investor says tech giants could even start dispensing financial advice.

It may take them some time to get there. Current accounts are "sticky": according to Novantas, a financial consultancy, only 8% of American retail customers switch bank each year. Yet they should enjoy having more choice. Free perks and a great user experience could sway them, especially if they know that a bank is in charge of the sensitive bits.

Lenders will also welcome Big Tech—at least initially. Distribution accounts for half of operating costs at America's typical retail bank, says Gerard du Toit of Bain, a consultancy. Tying up with a GAFA would be a neat way to access new deposits, a cheap source of funding.

Yet as Big Tech starts to own consumer relationships, banks could lose clout. They may be forced to give away more data and fees, says Andrei Brasoveanu of Accel, a venture-capital firm. They could end up akin to utilities, providing low-margin financial plumbing. Squeezed profits could lead to a wave of mergers and closures. Digital upstarts will also feel the heat, especially if Big Tech cross-subsidises its financial offerings.

Regulators have so far seen new entrants in financial services as a welcome catalyst for the innovation banks have failed to foster. That could change if the giants charge in. At the Web Summit Margrethe Vestager, the European Union's competition commissioner and a GAFA sceptic, mused about the risks to democracy if tech firms become too powerful to oversee and regulate. "We can reach for the potential," she told the amped-up audience in Lisbon. "But we can also do something to control the dark sides."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WFT-65P1-JBJ7-N0RF-00000-00Big tech takes Morrison's G20 Christchurch resolution in its stride2019-06-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:24:37ZLexisNexisBig tech takes Morrison's G20 Christchurch resolution in its stridePaul Smith

Facebook, Google and Twitter are among those pledging to do more to block terrorist content as Scott Morrison took G20 kudos for leading a global edict.

Global technology giants including Facebook and Google have greeted the release of a Scott Morrison-led G20 statement demanding greater action against the spread of terrorist content, by saying they were already doing everything being asked of them, and also signed off an Australian Taskforce report pledging to do the same thing.

The Prime Minister claimed political kudos over the weekend for corralling the world's leaders into signing a strongly-worded statement - separate to the communique issued at the conclusion of the G20 - that said the rule of law must operate the same online as offline.

It suggested legislative measures would result if a repeat of the Christchurch Massacre live-streaming occurred.

On Sunday morning Mr Morrison and Communications Minister Paul Fletcher also released a report from the Australian taskforce to combat terrorist and extremely violent material online, which identified nine areas where tech companies would "take further steps" to stop the spread of the content.

The taskforce comprised Facebook, YouTube, Amazon, Microsoft and Twitter, along with internet service providers Telstra, Vodafone, TPG and Optus.

It had promised to come back to government with suggestions following a meeting convened by the Prime Minister in March, where social media executives were threatened with jail terms for failing to police content.

"Social media companies are on notice. If they don't deliver on their commitments, we will move to legislate and do so quickly," Mr Morrison said in a statement on Sunday.

"Social media companies need to step up and recognise their responsibilities to ensure their platforms are not being weaponised by violent terrorists and extremists.

"We're doing everything we can with new laws and tighter controls at home and with our international partners to stop social media platforms being abused."

The big tech platforms, particularly Facebook and Google, are already in the legislative crosshairs in Australia because of their effect on competition in the media and advertising sectors.

The competition regulator handed its long-awaited final report for the Digital Platforms Inquiry to the government over the weekend, which will be publicly released once it has been assessed.

They responded to the glare of being called out at the G20 with responses that both indicated respect and agreement with the gravity of needing to better police terrorist content, while observing that there was essentially nothing new in the weekends' proclamations.

The tech companies had previously pledged to address the same concerns in May when New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern and French President Emmanuel Macron, led a "Christchurch Call," an international accord to demand the better policing of terrorism content.

The main difference with this weekend's G20 statement was that US President Donald Trump signed it, having snubbed the Christchurch Call.

"We have zero tolerance for terrorist content on our platforms. Over the last few years we have invested heavily in human review teams and smart technology that helps us quickly detect, review, and remove this type of content," a Google spokesman said.

"We are committed to leading the way in developing new technologies and standards for identifying and removing terrorist content. We are working with government agencies, law enforcement and across industry, including as a founding member of the Global Internet Forum To Counter Terrorism, to keep this type of content off our platforms."

A spokesman for Facebook Australia meanwhile said it welcomed the government's announcement of the taskforce report as its implementation of the Christchurch Call.

"Since the horrific terrorist attacks in New Zealand, we've been reviewing what more we can do to limit our services from being used to cause harm or spread hate," the spokesman said.

"In May, we announced restrictions to who can use Facebook Live and met with world leaders in Paris to sign the New Zealand Government's Christchurch Call to Action.

"We also co-developed a nine-point industry plan in partnership with Microsoft, Twitter, Google and Amazon, which outlines the concrete steps we're taking to address the abuse of technology to spread terrorist content."

A Twitter Australia spokesman said the promotion of terrorism was against its rules, and that the company's CEO Jack Dorsey had already attended the G7 event in Paris earlier this year as an indication of its commitment to supporting international measures.

"We are committed to removing this content and protecting the health of the public conversation," the spokesman said.

"We continue to share a common goal with governments across the world and our industry peers to find impactful solutions to counter extremism online ... We will continue to work together to help keep Australians safe online through the Consensus Report and our partnership with the Australian Taskforce to Combat Violent Terrorist and Extreme Material Online."

The taskforce report on Sunday pledged technical responses, such as greater sharing of intelligence between rival platforms, introducing algorithms to steer users away from unsavoury content and clear appeals mechanisms to enable users to challenge the moderation of content deemed to flout the rules.

It also said account validation for users allowed to live-stream content would be strengthened and that all platforms should have the same level of accelerated review of content flagged as terrorist or extremely violent as YouTube.

Less clear from the report is the eventual operation of a new "content blocking framework," which would see ISPs blocking content during an "online crisis event."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5NVR-5561-JBJ7-N1FH-00000-00Big tech takes over the world2017-06-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:24:37ZLexisNexisBig tech takes over the worldJohn Kehoe

Are Amazon, Apple, Facebook, Google and Microsoft too powerful or great for consumers?

It's not just Australia that's getting unnerved by the looming arrival of Amazon, the rise of so called platform giants is unsettling traditional business everywhere.

Amazon's shock $US13.7 billion ($18.1 billion) offer to buy upscale organic grocer Whole Foods Market underlines how America's technology giants are extending their reach across the economy to cement themselves as the most powerful forces in modern capitalism.

In a tectonic shift that's disrupting business and benefiting consumers, the cashed-up Amazon, Apple, Facebook, Google's parent Alphabet, and Microsoft are making big bets in markets traditionally outside the realms of technology.

Ambitious billionaire bosses such as Jeff Bezos and Mark Zuckerberg are targeting a bigger share of consumer wallets and aiming to connect with billions of consumers worldwide.

No industry seems safe to disruption. Big tech is applying expertise in software and data to diversify into retail, automobile-making via driverless cars, banking, media, online videos, healthcare solutions and drones, to name just a few.

Darrel West, founding director of the Centre for Technology Innovation at the Brookings Institution (a think tank), says: "We are headed for a few big players with companies with software tools allowing them to be strong in a variety of different sectors."

Apple, Alphabet, Microsoft and Amazon are the world's most valuable public companies by market capitalisation. Facebook is in the top 10 and is an advertising revenue juggernaut.

Combined, these five titans are worth almost $US3 trillion ($3.9 trillion), more than double the size of the Australian economy.

Chetan Sharma, a Seattle-based mobile and data consultant, says these giants will continue to push cloud computing, consumer analytics and artificial intelligence into new areas.

The business and technology convergence has triggered grumblings from sceptics, who worry such leviathans could wipe out traditional businesses, turn into anti-competitive oligopolies and destroy jobs, as automation replaces workers at the supermarket checkout, driving cars and conducting health scans.

"Amazon eats the world," boomed one headline this week.

"Tech's 'Frightful 5" was how The New York Times recently characterised the trend.

Some observers, such as Harvard Business School digital academic Jeffrey Rayport, argue platform companies have become "winner takes all" in their markets and increasingly look like monopolies.

Google controls about 90 per cent of the internet search market in Australia and Europe. Amazon, which has already decimated bookstores and is hurting shopping malls, is easily America's biggest online retailer. Facebook dominates social media. Apple sold 78 million smartphones last year.

US President Donald Trump threatened during last year's election to "go after" Amazon's billionaire founder Bezos for anti-competitive practices.

"Because he's got a huge antitrust problem because he's controlling so much, Amazon is controlling so much of what they are doing," Trump said.

Trump seemed motivated by the hardline reporting by The Washington Post, which Bezos also owns.

Yet when Trump this week hosted Bezos and top tech executives including Apple chief Tim Cook, Microsoft boss Satya Nadella, IBM head Ginni Rometty and Alphabet chairman Eric Schmidt (Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg declined the White House invite), there was little talk about anti-competitive issues and more focus on how big tech could make government more efficient and create well-paying jobs.

Trump might have been influenced by his outside tech adviser, PayPal co-founder Peter Thiel, who writes in his top-selling book Zero to One "there is no reason technology should be limited to computers".

"Creative monopoly means new products that benefit everybody and sustainable profits for the creator," Thiel notes.

Still, the European Union is pursuing Google for alleged anti-competitive practices in Europe and there is a growing chorus calling for similar reviews in other markets.

Tech's dominance is indisputable as they leverage off the "network effect" of cutting across various industries.

However, the evidence on any monopoly domination, at least to date, suggests concerns are overblown.

"It is arguably a more fragile dominance than 20 years ago," says Joshua Meltzer, an Australian expat and senior fellow who focuses on digital trade issues at the Brookings Institution in Washington.

The tech industry is not only highly disruptive against non-tech players, but former internet high flyers have also fallen victim to the creative destruction.

Myspace, an early social media network, was obliterated by Facebook.

Yahoo! dominated the internet search market in the 1990s before Google took over. Yahoo! has spectacularly unravelled and was recently acquired by Verizon Communications for $US5.5 billion, a shadow of the near $US140 billion peak in the dotcom bubble era in 2000.

Fellow internet pioneer America Online (AOL), the software services company that allowed computer users to access the internet community, suffered a similar fate after broadband destroyed its dial-up internet access model.

And as Thiel notes, just when the US government moved to regulate IBM as a monopoly due to its dominance in desktop computers and software, Microsoft and Intel emerged as the disrupters.

Eric Goldman, a Silicon Valley lawyer turned director of the High Tech Law Institute at Santa Clara University, says the competitive environment in the internet industry changes rapidly so it's dangerous for governments to intervene.

"It remains to be seen if that diversification succeeds, let alone if they get monopoly power."

Furthermore, giant and dominant companies have always been a ubiquitous feature of the US market economy.

The so-called industrialist "robber barons" of the late 19th century, such as railway operators, oil barons including the Rockefellers and Wall Street financiers, had outsized influence on the economy, policy and politics.

Australia, partly due to its small population, is dominated by oligopolies in banking, supermarkets and airlines.

In the US, the once-dominant retail department chain Sears owned and sold almost everything, including Allstate insurance, clothing, car rentals, bicycles, tools, music records, electrical goods and farm machinery, to just name a few business lines.

In a twist of irony, Sears recently announced the closure of 150 stores. Struggling to stay afloat, its share price has crashed to below $US7 from a peak of $US192 a decade ago.

The reason? Amazon's online sales model is decimating shopping malls.

Certainly, Amazon is turning into a sprawling conglomerate across e-commerce, cloud computing, online subscription television, small business loans, artificial intelligence and in-house devices.

Yet the idea Amazon epitomises the so-called "winner takes all" economy appears overstated.

Jeremy Philips, a New York-based Spark Capital Growth partner who invests in tech start-ups, says in many categories the largest tech companies compete vigorously against each other, such as online music and videos.

In areas such as driverless cars and drone deliveries, "there are certainly no winners yet and it is not clear that there are scale or network effects in operation that will lead to that", says Joshua Gans, chair in technical innovation and entrepreneurship at the University of Toronto.

In the future, however, it is possible this time will be different and the tech giants may become too powerful.

Competitors and regulators will need to be wary if the valuable big data that digital companies control concentrates too much power in too few hands and blocks the emergence of competitors.

The databases and algorithms that Amazon, Google and Facebook control from internet searches and clicks may prove incredibly valuable and necessary for success.

That gives these powerhouses an advantage in gleaning insights into people's behaviour, consumer preferences and personal characteristics.

In theory, competitors might be able to access this data but the expense of building such huge databases could become prohibitive.

Spark Capital's Phillips acknowledges the ground might be being laid for future monopolies, but argues the five big tech companies are competing "vigorously" on data so consumers are not under threat any time soon.

"Data may make it harder for new entrants to compete - but people tend to systematically underestimate the level of technological and business model innovation," Phillips says.

He adds: "Time will tell, but right now all of this competition makes it a great time to be a consumer."

Regardless, Sharma says the regulatory regimes are completely unprepared to deal with this new reality. "They can evaluate Google under the 'advertising' umbrella but have no way to understand the implications of their massive artificial intelligence engine applied to new areas like autonomous vehicles, commerce and connectivity," he says.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5T04-Y491-JD3N-50WF-00000-00Big Tech takes seat at privacy laws table2018-08-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:24:37ZLexisNexisWSJPg. 25Big Tech takes seat at privacy laws tableJohn D. McKinnon Marc Vartabedian

US tech companies, battered over their handling of consumers' personal data, are hoping to get ahead of the public and legal fallout by working with policymakers to help shape potential new federal privacy legislation.

The effort by tech coalitions such as the Information Technology Industry Council - representing internet giants such as Facebook, Amazon.com, Alphabet unit Google and Salesforce.com - comes after the industry has fended off many types of federal action on privacy for years.

"There's been such a shift" in industry views "that I really think the time is now," Karen Zacharia, chief privacy officer at Verizon Communications, said at a Brookings Institution conference on privacy legislation last month. "We need to go forward and do it." The likely elements of the legislation, which are taking shape in talks among industry represent-atives, Trump administration officials and politicians, would include features that politically powerful tech companies are urging.

Importantly, the legislation would almost certainly pre-empt regulation of online privacy by states such as California, which recently adopted its own tough new privacy law. Firms fear state-by-state rules could create a burdensome patchwork of regulation.

Compared with the California law and new privacy rules in the EU, the new US legislation is likely to be less stringent. Amid opposition from Republicans and many in the industry, federal rules probably wouldn't offer many opportunities for consumers to file private lawsuits over violations, although that might change if Democrats take over one or both chambers of congress as a result of the autumn elections.

Federal legislation is likely to hand much of the work of writing detailed privacy rules to the Federal Trade Commission, which has nominal authority in the area now but few regulatory weapons.

Another issue getting attention is restricting the potential for bias by companies and their business customers against users based on ethnicity and other categories.It also appears unlikely that the bill would include some related but highly controversial items such as legislation to set new legal standards for preventing consumer-data breaches or federal internet regulation. Existing laws affecting sensitive medical and educational data would probably remain unchanged.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60G8-J271-JBCN-4029-00000-00Big Tech tells Congress it doesn't stifle competition2020-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:24:37ZLexisNexisMAINPg. 17ABig Tech tells Congress it doesn't stifle competition

WASHINGTON -- Leaders of Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google fended off accusations Wednesday that their companies stifle competition, under intense questioning from lawmakers investigating Big Tech's market dominance.

Amazon's Jeff Bezos, in his first appearance before Congress, Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg, Sundar Pichai of Google and Tim Cook of Apple sometimes struggled to answer pointed questions about their business practices even as they provided data highlighting how competitive their markets are and the value of their innovation and essential services to consumers.

Among the toughest questions for Google and Amazon involved accusations that they used their dominant platforms to scoop up data about competitors in a way that gave them an unfair advantage.

Bezos said that he couldn't guarantee that Amazon had not accessed seller data to make competing products, an allegation that the company and its executives have previously denied.

Regulators in the U.S. and Europe have scrutinized Amazon's relationship with the businesses that sell on its site and whether the online shopping giant has been using data from the sellers to create its own private-label products.

"We have a policy against using seller specific data to aid our private label business," Bezos said in a response to a question from U.S Rep. Pramila Jayapal, a Washington Democrat. "But I can't guarantee to you that that policy hasn't been violated."

Pichai struggled as the antitrust panel's Democratic chairman, Rhode Island Rep. David Cicilline, accused the company of leveraging its dominant search engine to steal ideas and information from other websites and manipulating its results to drive people to its own digital services to boost its profits.

Facebook, in turn, faced renewed focus on its gobbling up of competitors. Rep. Jerrold Nadler, the Democrat who heads the House Judiciary Committee, told Zuckerberg that documents obtained from the company "tell a very disturbing story" of Facebook's acquisition of the Instagram messaging service. He said the documents show Zuckerberg called Instagram a threat that could "meaningfully hurt" Facebook.

Zuckerberg responded that Facebook viewed Instagram as both a competitor and a "complement" to Facebook's services, but also acknowledged that it competed with Facebook on photo-sharing.

-- ASSOCIATED PRESS

Google's Pichai Amazon's Bezos Apple's Cook Facebook's Zuckerberg

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60G8-D1D1-JBJN-M005-00000-00Big Tech testifies in US Congress about digital domination2020-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:24:37ZLexisNexisBig Tech testifies in US Congress about digital domination


Washignton, Jul 29 (EFE).- The heads of the world's four major technology players, Google, Amazon, Facebook and Apple, are facing a U.S. Congressional hearing on Wednesday that will be questioned about whether they have accumulated too much power and their dominant position does not allow free competition.


Sundar Pichai (Google), Jeff Bezos (Amazon), Mark Zuckerberg (Facebook) and Tim Cook (Apple) will answer questions from the House Judiciary Committee, which has investigated for a year the impact on the competition by these four tech giants dominating markets such as online ads, searches, e-commerce, social media, messaging and mobile hardware and software.
The four companies together annually enter about $800 billion, nearly three times Colombia's gross domestic product (GDP), and have a market capitalization of $4.7 trillion, larger than the size of the German economy.
Amazon, for example, dominates much of global e-commerce, as well as the important data center and cloud industry with Amazon Web Services.
Google is the gateway to the internet and owns the most widely used operating system in mobile; Facebook is the conglomerate by which much of the world's inhabitants receive or share information, and Apple controls about a quarter of the "smartphones" market and one-tenth of the computer market.
This will be the most important audience for the tech sector since the U.S. government tried to chop Microsoft for its dominant position two decades ago and brings the echoes of when in the 1990s the big tobacco companies sat down to answer about tobacco addiction and the industry was reformed forever.
Congressmen's questions could focus not only on free competition, but also on labor practices, privacy, electoral influence and misinformation, national security and international trade.
US President Donald Trump issued his first warning this morning, especially in the social media realm, by ordering the Federal Communications Commission (FCC), the telecoms regulator, to clarify "whether social media platforms can editorialize user expression."
Commerce asked the FCC to examine whether content "healing" is done in "good faith" and called for transparency in moderation practices.
"The president will continue to fight against online censorship of unfair, un-American, and politically biased Americans," the White House said.
Trump has declared war on social media, especially Twitter, since Twitter marked some of his tweets with warnings for disclosing false information about the election, something that violates the platform's rules of use.
Facebook has been more cautious in curbing content disclosed by Trump on its platform that could violate its rules of use.
The sword Trump hangs over the heads of digital platforms like Facebook, Twitter or Youtube is section 230 of the Communications Decency Act of 1996, which states that a social network cannot be treated as an "editor."
In any case, the audience, in addition to complex (the four CEOs will sit together), promises to be unpredictable and complicated for congressmen who in the past have shown difficulties in understanding the technical background of some of the services provided by "Big Tech" and who have before them the best-connected people who invest more money in influencing Washington.

urn:contentItem:60G8-D151-DY1R-B52M-00000-00Big Tech testifies in US Congress about digital domination2020-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:24:37ZLexisNexisBig Tech testifies in US Congress about digital domination


The heads of the world's four major technology, Google, Amazon, Facebook and Apple, are facing a U.S. Congressional hearing on Wednesday that they will be questioned about whether they have accumulated too much power and their dominant position does not allow free competition.


Sundar Pichai (Google), Jeff Bezos (Amazon), Mark Zuckerberg (Facebook) and Tim Cook (Apple) will answer questions from the House Judiciary Committee, which has investigated for a year the impact on the competition by these four tech giants dominating markets such as online ads, searches, e-commerce, social media, messaging and mobile hardware and software.
The four companies together annually enter about $800 billion, nearly three times Colombia's gross domestic product (GDP), and have a market capitalization of $4.7 billion, larger than the size of the German economy.
Amazon, for example, dominates much of global e-commerce, as well as the important data center and cloud industry with Amazon Web Services.
Google is the gateway to the internet and owns the most widely used operating system in mobile; Facebook is the conglomerate by which much of the world's inhabitants receive or share information, and Apple controls about a quarter of the "smartphones" market and one-tenth of the computer market.
This will be the most important audience for the tech sector since the U.S. government tried to chop Microsoft for its dominant position two decades ago and brings the echoes of when in the 1990s the big tobacco companies sat down to answer about tobacco addiction and the industry was reformed forever.
Congressmen's questions could focus not only on free competition, but also on labor practices, privacy, electoral influence and misinformation, national security and international trade.
US President Donald Trump issued his first warning this morning, especially in the social media realm, by ordering the Federal Communications Commission (FCC), the telecoms regulator, to clarify "whether social media platforms can editorialize user expression."
Commerce asked the FCC to examine whether content "healing" is done in "good faith" and called for transparency in moderation practices.

urn:contentItem:60G8-D1D1-JBJN-M053-00000-00Big Tech testifies in US Congress on digital domination2020-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:24:37ZLexisNexisBig Tech testifies in US Congress on digital domination

Archive photo dated July 29, 2020 of the Facebook Likes in Menlo Park, California, UNITED States.
Washignton, Jul 29.- The heads of the four global Big Tech, Google, Amazon, Facebook and Apple, are facing a U.S. Congressional hearing on Wednesday that they will be questioned about whether they have accumulated too much power and their dominant position does not allow free competition.


Sundar Pichai (Google), Jeff Bezos (Amazon), Mark Zuckerberg (Facebook) and Tim Cook (Apple) will answer questions from the House Judiciary Committee, which has investigated for a year the impact on the competition by these four tech giants dominating markets such as online ads, searches, e-commerce, social media, messaging and mobile hardware and software.
The four companies together annually enter about $800 billion, nearly three times Colombia's gross domestic product (GDP), and have a market capitalization of $4.7 trillion, larger than the size of the German economy.
Amazon, for example, dominates much of global e-commerce, as well as the important data center and cloud industry with Amazon Web Services.
Google is the gateway to the internet and owns the most widely used operating system in mobile; Facebook is the conglomerate for which much of the world's inhabitants receive or share information, and Apple controls about a quarter of the "smartphones" market and one-tenth of the computer market.
This will be the most important audience for the tech sector since the U.S. government tried to chop Microsoft for its dominant position two decades ago and brings the echoes of when in the 1990s the big tobacco companies sat down to answer about tobacco addiction and the industry was reformed forever.
Congressmen's questions could focus not only on free competition, but also on labor practices, privacy, electoral influence and misinformation, national security and international trade.
US President Donald Trump issued his first warning this morning, especially in the social media realm, by ordering the Federal Communications Commission (FCC), the telecoms regulator, to clarify "whether social media platforms can editorialize user expression."
Commerce asked the FCC to examine whether content "healing" is done in "good faith" and called for transparency in moderation practices.
"The president will continue to fight against online censorship of unjust, anti-American, and politically biased Americans," the White House said.
Trump has opposed how social media politicizes and censors Conservative Americans, especially Twitter.
Trump alleges that digital platforms such as Facebook, Twitter or Youtube, under section 230 of the Communications Decency Act of 1996, states that a social network cannot be treated as an "editor".
In any case, the audience, in addition to complex (the four CEOs will sit together),promises to be unpredictable and complicated for congressmen who in the past have shown difficulties in understanding the technical background of some of the services that "Big Tech" provide and that have before them the people who are better connected and who invest more money in influencing Washington.

urn:contentItem:6071-CX61-DY1R-B1K1-00000-00Big tech, the biggest threat to traditional banking2020-06-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:24:37ZLexisNexisBig tech, the biggest threat to traditional banking


Companies such as Apple,Amazon,Facebook and Samsung are viewed by the industry as the biggest threat to the traditional banking business, according to financial sector specialists who believe that big technology can even pose a concentration problem for the cloud services they offer to other financial firms.


The IX Minsait Media Trend Report,for which 40 members of the financial sector were interviewed in Latin American countries and 400 users of its services, four out of 10 Mexicans believe that big tech or big tech will provide a better service than traditional banking and five out of 10 think their service will be the same.
According to the report, in Latin America, big techs have taken advantage of the information they obtain from the interaction with their users to leverage the start of their financial services offering. Recently, Facebook announced the start of its payment services through Whatsapp and Samsung and Apple have been advancing in the market for payment wallets and contactless payments.
It is precisely the wallets of devices such as those of Samsung or Apple,that have the greatest chance of surviving in the next five years, above banking wallets and those of payment ecosystems, such as Mercado Pago, refers to the document of Minsait, the technology division of Spain's Indra.
Ernesto Terríquez, Director of Financial Services at Minsait,explained in interview that while at the beginning of the digital disruption process, the banking sector recognized fintech as its main threat; big tech came to offer financial services in Latin America in late 2019 and early 2020 with a high technological component, the penetration of their brands and the financial support they have to invest and to offer new financial products.
"Amazon has created an ecosystem around e-commerce and I think it's one step away from starting to offer financing for product purchases," Terríquez said. This model is already applied by Argentina's Mercado Libre in Mexico, which offers consumer credits but also of work, through its Mercado Créditodivision.
Terríquez added that while traditional banking has restrictions on reaching the unbanked base of the Mexican population, the great technology are able to reach any segment of the population pyramid so that its product can be adopted more easily.
Minsait's report quotes Alfonso Estévez, CEO of EZ Wallet, a Mexican mobile banking platform, who is convinced that the big technology will be "the big competitors of the consolidated suppliers, with their technological tools, their databases and their digital strength.
"Banks should be more concerned about them because fintech's strategy is not to compete with banks or bigtech – with whom they cannot - but to be part of their ecosystems or create their own ecosystems," Estévez says in the report.
However, for Fabricio Ikeda, director of the Fraud and Regulatory Compliance area of the data analysis company for the banking sector FICO in Latin America, the dynamics between traditional and large technology banking are more one of alliances than competition.
"The advantage of traditional banking over big tech is theability to invest and being able to send new products to its customers, but at the same time when one of these market participants enters the market, as has happened in countries such as Mexico, Brazil and Colombia, what it does is generate more value to the industry," Ikeda said.
